title: March 2019, Encountering Ethics Workshop, TU Delft
content: Viktor took part in the workshop which included interviewing (people impersonating) smart objetcs, building scenarios from the objects perspective and working on a manifesto for more desireable paradigms of smartness. Read the full report here for thoughts about extending care to objects, pushing towards a more-than-human centred design and the workshop's relevancy for the Thinking Toys for Commoning project.

title: February 2019, Micro Residency 1b
content: Designers Sarah Hermanutz and Andreas Rau visited our lab and project for a week. Together with Michaela they were working on a multi-media installation that uses an immersive and responsive environment to create sensitivity for metabolic processes and vegetal life. The resulting installation "Give and Take" creates an experience that leads the observer from micro to macro scales of vital processes. The immersive environment induces a perceptional link with thermal, climatic, meteorological processes that are enacted in partial response to the engaging individual.

Playful Agent-Based Modeling as Thinking-Toys for Urban Commoners” and Michaela about “Unsettling design - Material Encounters and Relational Practices”.

The conversation addressed the potential entanglement of technologies with alternative forms of living together from different scales and levels. We also tried to discuss the affective and fantastic ingredients of commoning with tech – such as the phantasms of decentralization. With our great team and John Evans and Cade Diehm.

title: April 2018, Kick-Off Meeting
content:
In order to open up our thinking space and connect with possible academic peers, we organised a kick-off meeting around "commoning", "gaming" and "modelling". Our central question for the discussions was: How could playful setups enable grasping, negotiating and thinking critically about the complexities of commoning in urban neighborhoods?

On day one of the two-day workshop, participants shortly presented their perspective on the above question by introducing some of their related work or projects. On the second day we discussed and exchanged ideas, concepts, tool-sets, and approaches within the triangle of commoning, modeling and playing by a playful conversation and prototyping format.

Participants: Adam van Heerden, Bruce Edmonds, Gabriele Ferri, Geeske Scholz, Gilly Krajevsky, Ivo Balmer, Jelena Viskovic, Mary Dellenbaugh-Losse, Shusha Niederberger, Panayotis Antoniadis, Paul Chaney, Sebastian Quack, Roger Portmann and Tobias Willimann.

title: February 2018, Masquerade for Commoning
content: Our team took part at transmediale 2018 face value with the workshop "Masquerade for Commoning" which we held on Sunday 4th of Feb. Since we then just started, we used this lovely occasion as a team building effort with guest colleague Felix Gerloff from the lab and external guest Kevin Rittberger. Kevin was involved earlier in 2015 with "Syntegrity". Here a more detailed announcement of the workshop: Masquerade for Commoning wants to encourage you to tackle face value – Transmediale 2018’s thought-provoking trigger – via modulating the idea of the mask. Would a playful masquerade be helpful in order to discuss how we could respond to current practices of taking things at face value too fast and at the same time enable us to self-critically recognize moments when we also take our own ideals, values, and utopias at face value? What kind of biases and exploitative mechanisms are involved when we think, for example, about alternative models for creating value together? How would the masquerade unfold if we modulated face value with commoning? Commoning => a verb expressing the joint action of creating things together by drawing on a network of human and non-human relations created with the expectation of mutual care, aid, benefits and a shared understanding that some things could belong to all of us. Mask => an object or filter that can modify an identity in order to lie about it, take on a role, represent another, assume a collective identity, make identities equal, abstract an identity, reveal an identity, take possession of the mask's powers... Masquerade => a joint action of assuming and executing modified identities which usually involves the creation of new relationships between masked identities and produces a complex situation of co-dependencies. Masquerade for Commoning suggests to understand face value spectrally, not only dialectically and reconsider current models of valorization as producers of unwanted artifacts of our agricultural software that has been running for over five thousand years. We want to modulate and synthesize the mask, the act of masking, the masquerade, faces and values with cultural practices of commoning. The mask as a tangible artifact could enable different modes of understanding, enacting and modelling the dynamics that is at work in commoning. Performed by the workshop participants or in a real-life situation, the Masquerade for Commoning might shed new light on different constellations, social relations and dependencies between individual agents and their environments. In our times, we – you and us – are confronted with a difficult riddle: How can we imagine and build a radically different system of valorization and distribution while facing the constraints of current (neoliberal) geopolitical powers? Commoning, at face value, might be a simple and evident solution but it surely involves drama. More than a political theory or philosophy, commoning is an active, living process which involves a complex ecosystem of things, persons, infrastructures, resources, technologies, and architectures. Here, the mask comes into play almost seamlessly — etymologically related to ghosts and darkness and even mockery, masks have evolved into agents of impersonation, of taking on a role in a drama or performance. Masks are used to abstract certain aspects of an individual but also to conjure more-than-human superpowers. Masks are old artifacts humans used since immemorial times in rituals and on special occasions. A flat mask, moreover, as provided here, has a back and a front side. Thus it embodies the principle of binaries. Would that be a pathway to digitality? Join our session to collaboratively and playfully discuss, sketch, design masks and model constellations of commoning. The blank mask accompanying this print (PDF output) is our invitation to the first Masquerade for Commoning at the last day of Transmediale 2018 (Feb 4th (Sunday), 14:00–17:00, K2, HKW).

title: November 2018, A first model about work time organization (Ämtli-Manager)
content:
A first model about work time organization (Ämtli-Manager), 11.2018   With this agent-based model, we study the phenomenon of commoning (sharing common resources in a durable way) in the context of  sustainable living initiatives and co-housing projects in Switzerland. We focus on the distribution of working time that members  voluntarily contribute to community life. When are they feeling their contribution is fair? Are the others also behaving fairly?  How can we make sure urgent tasks are done? What are the tipping points in agents behaviour? What tipping points can we observe on  the level of the community? 

The model is informed by our discussions with three co-housing initiatives (Warmbächli, LeNa and NeNa1), conducted in April 2018. 

We identified an interest in establishing and tracking fair division of work among the members, while at the same time not wanting to be too intrusive on member’s privacy and individual contribution. Some questions we retained are “how much would it cost to not  clean the kitchen when it is your turn to do it?” (NeNa1) and “How to measure how much volunteering time each member needs to contribute to the community?” (LeNa).

Ämtli manager is one complex model that addresses these questions. It is a system that identifies tasks that need to be done urgently (looking at how much time has passed since the task was done) and finds community members that could take up a task and acquire right to rest and relax. They, in return, can accept or refuse to take up the task - a decision based on both the amount of resting time the community member has acquired and the interest they have in doing that particular task. Agents have different personalities which  determine their strategy for accepting or refusing tasks: they can be “curious” or “perfectionist”, “geniessers” or “capitalists”.

Four tasks that describe common life appear in the model: ‘food depot management’ (‘‘Lebensmitteldepot’), ‘common kitchen maintenance’  (‘Großküchendienst’), ‘social work’ (‘Soziales’) and ‘facilities duty’ (‘Raumpflege’). A complex system of exchange of free time for work, combined with agents’ personalities, incentivises agents to pick up tasks and have the household running properly.

Fairness is measured in function of stress and forcing the agents are feeling. If all agents refuse to take up a task, one will be  forced and will therefore start feeling stressed. When that agent uses some of their resting time, the stress will decrease. If they  do not have any, stress level will grow. Depending largely on the composition of the community in terms of agents personality, brute  forcing will occur more or less often, affecting stress level of the community and signaling its dysfunctionalities (when agents need  to be forced, we can assume common facilities are taken care of to a bare minimum).

The model outputs data that consist of time-based readings of states of agents' parameters. We experimented with different modes of  visualisation of this model, looking at it historically, so that we can identify emergent behaviours and tipping points. We also  looked at the data from the points of view of community members, tasks that need to be done and the whole environment (micro- and  macro-views). Visualization remains an important aspect of this work. 

We can present some preliminary insights and findings already. For example, when all four types of community members are equally present,  it tends to happen that the stress of all agents increases, except for those that we named “capitalists” - their stress stays at a  reasonably low level and they are rarely “brute forced”. Contrarily, in a society made only of “geniessers”, stress stays at a typically  low level. We can interpret this as a sort of recommendation for the behaviour in the community (be all geniessers) or community composition, although this would be rather far-fetched. We expect to observe more such patterns and tipping points when running the model in the future.

title: Denkspielzeug für Commoning
content:
Die gemeinschaftlich-nachhaltige Nutzung und Organisation von Ressourcen ist komplex. Mit einem Fokus auf alternativ-utopisch inspirierte Stadt-Nachbarschaften in der Schweiz schlägt das Forschungsprojekt eine exemplarische Untersuchung und gestalterisch-explorative Entwicklung medialer Denkwerkzeuge vor, mit deren Hilfe die Komplexität solcher Prozesse besser veranschaulicht werden können.

Gemeinschaftlich-nachhaltig genutzte Ressourcen, wie etwa Lebensmittel oder kommunikative Infrastrukturen wie Wifi, werden Commons genannt. Commoning meint die Aktivität des gemeinsamen Teilens dieser Ressourcen. Der durch zahlreiche alternativ-utopisch inspirierte Projekte formulierter Anspruch, infrastrukturelle Aspekte des urbanen Alltagslebens durch Commoning selbstverantwortlich und alternativ zu gestalten, wirft einige Fragen auf. Denn aufgrund der hohen Komplexität, die mit der gemeinschaftlichen Nutzung von Ressourcen bisweilen einhergeht, kann das einzelne Gemeinschaftsmitglied sein Commoning und dessen Konsequenzen oft nicht bis ins letzte Detail und in all seinen Konsequenzen durchdenken. Besonders wenn es um ein verstehendes Erfahren unvorhersehbarer, komplex-adaptiver Vorgänge geht, kann er oder sie deren Ablauf, so unsere These, rein intuitiv und ohne die Hilfe veranschaulichender medialer Denkwerkzeuge, wie computerbasierte Modelle oder Szenarien, nicht mehr vollständig erfassen.

Aus diesem Grund wird im engen Austausch mit den Mitgliedern der schweizerischen Stadt-Nachbarschaftsprojekte NeNa1 in Zürich, LeNa in Basel und Warmbächli in Bern eine mobile, digitale Software-Anwendung entwickelt und erprobt. Dabei geht es um die spielerische Anregung und Erschließung neuer Denk- und Handlungsräume im Bereich des Commonings. Denn, auf diese Weise – so unser Ziel – könnten sich neue Wege für zukünftige gesellschaftliche Teilhabe- und Transformationsprozesse eröffnen.

Das vierjährige Projekt, in dem sowohl geistes- und sozialwissenschaftliche als auch gestalterische Methoden kombiniert werden, verfolgt zentral folgende Leitfrage: Wie lässt sich durch das gemeinschaftlich-experimentelle Gestalten und Entwickeln eines digitalen Spielsystems das Nachdenken über die intuitiv oft nicht nachvollziehbare Komplexität des Commoning anregen und Komplexität so spielerisch versteh- und besser verhandelbar machen?

title: April 2018, Kick-Off Tagung
content:
Um unseren Denkraum zu öffnen und uns mit möglichen Fachkollegen zu verbinden, organisierten wir eine Kick-Off Tagung rund um die Themen “commoning”, “gaming” und “modelling”. Unsere zentrale Frage für die Diskussionen lautete: Wie können spielerische Einrichtungen uns helfen, die Komplexität von gemeinsamem Wirken in urbanen Nachbarschaften zu verstehen, zu bewältigen und kritisch zu überdenken? 

Am ersten Tag des zweitägigen Workshops konnten die Teilnehmer ihre Perspektive bezüglich der vorhin gestellten Frage erklären, dies unter Einbezug und Vorstellung von verwandter Arbeit und Projekten. Am zweiten Tag diskutierten und tauschten wir Ideen, Konzepte, Arbeitstechniken und Herangehensweisen innerhalb des Dreiecks von “commoning”, “modelling” und “playing” aus, begleitet von spielerischer Konversation und der Entwicklung von Prototypen. 

Teilnehmer/Innen: Adam van Heerden, Bruce Edmonds, Gabriele Ferri, Geeske Scholz, Gilly Krajevsky, Ivo Balmer, Jelena Viskovic, Mary Dellenbaugh-Losse, Shusha Niederberger, Panayotis Antoniadis, Paul Chaney, Sebastian Quack, Roger Portmann and Tobias Willimann.

title: March 2019, Commoning and Tech Focus
content:
As part of the workshop with the co-housing cooperative NeNa1 from Zurich, we dedicated some time and thoughts to the questions about possible roles and impact of technologies on commoning practices. Technology is rarely seen as a resource to be shared, and the philosophy of degrowth can make us unsympathetic towards (cutting-edge) technical solutions (e.g. automation, AI, etc). Commoning with technology refers to both using technology, like an instrument, but also the need to make common how it works. One way of using tech is what we have presented earlier - working on computational models (e.g. Agent-based modelling) that depict some concrete aspects or situations, such as organization of voluntary work contributions by the community members, in order to find patterns and tipping points in complex community behaviours. 

In a different gesture, we wanted to explore scenarios in which communities would benefit from sharing information using open source technical systems, or sharing knowledge and creating tools that enable distant communication, recording and processing of information. We worked in groups and tried to trace out trends and tendencies in specific technical solutions or commoning practices 10 years ago, today and in 10 years.

The topics discussed touched upon personal communication (email -> wiki, chat platforms -> commons app), ubiquity and autonomy of infrastructure (telephone lines -> the internet -> self-determined autonomous networks) and cultural considerations (dialogue -> chat groups -> convergence of local and global discussion). We plan to explore how these topics could inform a future narrative and how they can be modeled using ABM.

title: March 2019, Workshop with NeNa1
content: Our second workshop with the Zurich cooperative, NeNa1, took place in three parts. First, Viktor presented his work on a toolkit that invites participants to experience how it feels to carry out  the tasks, called by the Ämtli manager ABM model. Then, we presented the model in detail, explained how it operates in detail and discussed the implementation of mechanisms (e.g. swapping) and parameters (e.g. stress, time_coin) that we observe when we run the model. At the end, Selena introduced the topic of commoning and tech as a ‘10yearchallenge’ - discussing the way certain technologies were used by housing cooperatives and communities in general, and asking to imagine the way these or other technologies will play a role in commoners lives in 10 (or more) years.

title: March 2019, Utopia Reshuffled: workshop at the OTHERWISE festival, Zurich
content:
What are Utopias about? How are new worlds described, new societies proposed? We identified some key elements in a selection of utopian classics like Thomas More's Utopia, Ursula K. le Guin's The Dispossessed or Hans Wiedmer's bolo'bolo and decided to take them as building blocks in a generative method for writing new stories about societies of the future. Using a deck of cards specially designed for this workshop, we confronted participants with a random configuration of pieces from different utopias and asked them to cross-breed contemporary thinking with historical utopism. They worked in groups to create five different narratives, inspired by their selection of cards. 

On the Wetopia island, people are organized by the ‘humarithm’ governing intelligence, and grouped around interests rather than blood relations. 

The Age of Mycelium addresses collapsed ecosystems with and artificial intelligence that engages an underground system of fungi into collaboration with women and men, a biodiverse intersectional network. 

The E-zero society is happy because it is emotion-free. The outer appearance is an indicator of one's inner state, and it is cared for by a ubiquitous social institution of Shamoons. 

Supercomputers control and decide in the society that Shkola is set out to change. A new kind of anthropocentrism arises from concerns with this artificial intelligence, as well as with the changing climate. 

Samadhi is an artificial state of supraconsciousness and a network of nodes-temples which Samadhian visit every 20 days to refresh their minds. The five beautifully crafted books were presented as a formal book launch at the end of the workshop.

title: May 2019, Micro Residency 2 with Sarah Grant
content: Sarah Grant, a Berlin-based media artist working with technical and organic manifestations of networks, spent a week at the lab. She worked with Selena to develop slime mould [Physarum polycephalum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physarum_polycephalum) communication models that show how information travels through a self-organised entity - a plasmodium supercell, a model of a community. Physarum polycephalum is a many-headed slime organism, studied for the way it is able to move, find food, and produce efficient networks between food sources. Starting from three chance-based scenarios - selecting cards from the Reshuffle Utopia card deck ([developed for the Utopia Reshuffled workshop at OTHERWISE festival](http://commoning.rocks/index.html#Otherwise_Workshop)) - Sarah tested nine setups using oats and food colouring to control the growth of the slime mould organism and observe the way the networks develop and transmit information. At the end of the residency, Sarah gave [a talk on her work and slime mould modeling experiment](https://www.ixdm.ch/modeling-utopia-with-slime-mould/) at the Critical Media Lab. A longer report can be found in [this document](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1MtLm5x0vm5aTqxOPM73jIoOCuYBr3orWxfPzRcv2MtQ/edit). The experiment is ongoing.

title: April 2019, Ämtli Manager Observations
content: During the month of April, in preparation for the last tweeks and updates to the Ämtli manager, we worked on developing a systematic way for observing the model states and documenting these in a consistent form. Driven by several simple questions, Selena tested different initial configurations, and then changed only certain parameters to see how, if at all, they affect the resulting macro-behaviour. Is there a setup where the community works harmoniously over long periods of time (several years)? Does the frequency and amount of swapping/brute forcing depend on commoner’s traits? All observations are noted in [file1](https://drive.google.com/open?id=101AxVMUiwd1Nb6RS6PYss0e5Iv_Nab5rc6wURT_EcpM) and [file2](https://docs.google.com/document/d/101AxVMUiwd1Nb6RS6PYss0e5Iv_Nab5rc6wURT_EcpM/edit?usp=sharing). Yann then programmed a batch-testing routine which enables comprehensive testing of all parameters in a semi-automated way. Notes on this way of exploring the model are following soon.

title: Feb – Mar 2019, Ämtli Manager UPDATE
content: Following months of evaluation and debugging, we decided to implement some necessary changes to the way Ämtli Manager works. Through intensive discussions, the team reached a better understanding of the model’s inner mechanisms and connections between values, settings and states. We used remodelling as an opportunity to document and explain the model elements, mechanisms and interactions, for which we designed a set of diagrams. The document with diagrams can be [downloaded here (pdf)](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1axA-3k1oW5B50rP0NIgdj210VMTbpdsH/view).

title: June 2019, Unconference in Cyprus
content: Selena presented the project’s focus on commoning and tech at the [Free/Libre Technologies, Arts and the Commons](https://unrf-unconference.futureworldscenter.org/) unconference, in Nicosia, Cyprus. The event was partly a conference, with parallel panel presentations (day 1) and partly an unconference, with round discussions and clusters (day 2). We worked together on to identifying topics, interests and challenges related to commoning, software, infrastructures and society. Both the presentations and the discussions within clusters will be published as conference proceedings.

title: January 2020, Thinking Toys at Biennial of Design, Ljubljana, Slovenia
content: Selena travelled to Ljubljana to give a [Thinking Toys for Commoning workshop](https://bio.si/en/program/events/46/2020-01-25/15-00/thinking-toys-for-commoning/) on tech and commoning as part of the 26th Biennial of Design, addressing the theme Common Knowledge. Participants discussed speculative future services attuned at commoning, in that they are community oriented, sustainable in terms of production and maintenance and promoting community resilience and independence. We came up with three proposals: *Disco Phone* that contracts and opens according to its user’s mental availability; *Robot Pigeon* delivering digital messages by moving physically between two persons and allowing for messages to be refused; *Invisibility Cloak* provided by the city authorities to protect citizens’ privacy. The projects entries for the Future of Commoning and IoT catalogue can be found [here](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1eiYiiyEUeRimsQobNy8aj1xcSAcNx0Ra/view?usp=sharing).

title: März 2019, Workshop mit NeNa1
content: Unser zweiter Workshop mit der Zürcher Genossenschaft, NeNa1, fand in drei Blöcken statt. Zuerst stellte Viktor seine Arbeit an einem Toolkit vor. Dieses lässt die Teilnehmenden erfahren, wie es sich anfühlt die Aufgaben, die sie vom Ämtli-Manager ABM-Modell erhalten, auszuführen. Dann stellten wir das Modell im Detail vor und diskutierten die Umsetzung von Mechanismen (z.B. Swapping) und Parametern (z.B. Stress, time_coin), die wir bei der Ausführung des Modells beobachten. Zum Schluss führte Selena das Thema Commoning und Technologie als eine '10yearchallenge' ein – und diskutierte die Art und Weise, wie bestimmte Technologien von Genossenschaften und Gemeinschaften im Allgemeinen verwendet wurden, und bat darum, sich vorzustellen, wie diese oder andere Technologien im Leben der Commoners in 10 (oder mehr) Jahren eine Rolle spielen werden.

title: Nov–Dez 2018, Ämtli-Manager Workshops
content: Wir setzten unsere Zusammenarbeit mit den Genossenschaften fort und führten zwei Workshops durch, in denen wir die erste Version unseres Ämtli-Managers (Arbeitstitel) testeten und Rückmeldungen zum Thema Arbeitszeitorganisation sammelten.

title: März 2019, Commoning und Technologie Workshop
content:
Im Rahmen des Workshops mit der Bau- und Wohngenossenschaft NeNa1 aus Zürich beschäftigten wir uns mit Fragen nach der möglichen Rolle und Auswirkung von Technik auf die gemeinsame Praxis. Selten betrachten wir Technologie als eine Ressource die geteilt werden soll und die Philosophie der Wachstumskritik kann eine Abneigung gegen hochmoderne technische Lösungen (z.B. Automatisierung, KI) hervorrufen. Commoning in Bezug auf Technologie meint sowohl die Verwendung von Technik, wie ein Gerät, als auch auf die Notwendigkeit, dessen Funktionsweise gemeinsam zu gestalten. Eine Möglichkeit, Technik zu nutzen, ist das, was wir zuvor vorgestellt haben – die Arbeit an Rechenmodellen (z.B. agentenbasierte Modelle), die einige konkrete Aspekte oder Situationen abbilden. Dies kann z.B. die Organisation von Freiwilligenarbeit der Gemeinschaftsmitglieder sein. So können Muster und Kipppunkte in komplexen Verhaltensweisen der Gemeinschaft gefunden werden. 

Zudem wollten wir Szenarien durchgehen, in denen die Gemeinschaften vom Teilen von Information profitieren können. Dies kann erreicht werden mit Hilfe von technischen Systemen mit offenem Quellcode (open source) oder auch durch die Erschaffung von Werkzeugen, die Fernkommunikation sowie die Aufzeichnung und Verarbeitung von Informationen ermöglichen. Wir arbeiteten in Gruppen und versuchten, Trends und Tendenzen in spezifischen technischen Lösungen oder gemeinsamen Praktiken vor 10 Jahren, heute und in 10 Jahren aufzuspüren.

Die diskutierten Themen berührten die persönliche Kommunikation (E-Mail -> Wiki, Chat-Plattformen -> Commons App), die Allgegenwart und Autonomie der Infrastruktur (Telefonleitungen -> Internet -> selbstbestimmte autonome Netzwerke) sowie auch kulturelle Überlegungen (Dialog -> Gesprächsgruppen -> Zusammenführung von lokaler und globaler Diskussion). Wir planen zu untersuchen, wie diese Themen in ein zukünftiges Narrativ einfliessen und mit Hilfe von ABMs modelliert werden können.

title: May 2019, Human Agent ABM Plugin
content:
The Human Agent ABM Plugin is a somewhat unwieldy immersive toy that turns human players into computer agents. The Plugin consists of a physical console with four mico-actions which connects to an agent-based computer model (running on a laptop) about sharing chores in a community. The micro-actions, in a very abstract manner, instantiate tasks like ‘child and elderly care’ or ‘food depot duty’. The player carries out the same chores and has the same choices than the computer agents, and as their actions are connected in real-time, the human player becomes one of many agents in the computer model. After sufficient playtime, the player develops a sense for how it would feel like to be part of the modelled system.

The Plugin is both single-player and massively multiplayer toy at the same time. The experience of playing is similar to attending to a very sophisticated Tamagotchi. The play is explorative and open-ended with no winning condition.

The Plugin is the result of a research through design process addressing the issues of complex toys, agent-based modelling, black boxes, scale critique, embodied vs formalised interaction, human and non-human play.

title: November 2019, Workshop at CUCR, Goldsmiths, University of London
content:
On November 8th Viktor hosted a workshop at the Centre for Urban and Community Studies at Goldsmiths, University of London on commoning and convivial urban infrastructures. More specifically, workshop participants explored the social and technological preconditions of predictive technologies enabling commoning minded urban infrastructures.

The workshop followed a critical prototyping approach. First participants discussed references on commoning, infrastrucutre, scale and predictive technologies. Then they reflected on the key issues through creating a paper prototype of commoning-minded prediction driven infrastructure for the circulation of urban resources.
